What's next for @MSFTResearch in China is anyone's guess. @pstAsiatech told me Microsoft could move AI researchers in China to Redmond, ‚Äúforming a kind of ‚Äòaway team‚Äô in the U.S.‚Äù 

I know I'll be watching....

https://t.co/x2Fkg1y3Gf

Of course, so much has changed in a short few years. Geopolitical tensions have ratcheted up to the point where the mere mention of tech collaboration with China is sensitive. @Microsoft has been forced to make some changes.

In reporting this story, I talked to two of @MSFTResearch's China lab founders, Rick Rashid & @nathanmyhrvold. Rashid shared memories of his teams in Redmond & Beijing working together in the early 2010s to build a groundbreaking real-time speech-to-text-to-translation system.

AI work out of @MSFTResearch in China not only has shown up in all sorts of Microsoft products over the years, it's ended up inside other AI. Take @MetaAI's new Make-A-Video AI system -- it came together using training and testing data sets out of MSRA in China.

AI practitioners agreed: ResNet was a big deal for deep learning globally. And Lee told me if it hadn't been for MSRA, ResNet -- discovered through the China team's unique focus on AI problem-solving US researchers eschewed -- "might have been left undiscovered outside of China."

When I first started thinking about reporting a @protocol series analyzing the realities and misconceptions about the so-called "AI race" between the U.S and China, I knew there had to be a chapter dedicated to Microsoft's storied lab in Beijing. https://t.co/x2Fkg1y3Gf
